TopicTitle: What do you think about new nuclear engine?

Articles.Content: This engine have thrust only 60, what it's advantage over other engines?

i think the point of it is that when in space it has a high specific impulse (something to do with thrust). when in deep space it has a low fuel consumption and still produces good results as far as movement goes. it does have a less then impressive result in atmosphere but i think it's meant for space.

Specific impulse hasn't anything to do with thrust; it tells you how efficient an engine is, i.e. how much your momentum (m*v) will be changed for each unit of fuel you burn. So in the case of the NERVA, its specific impulse being two times higher than the other engines at your disposal, the engine will need two times less fuel than the other engines to do the same momentum change. So with the NERVA you either need much less fuel to reach your destination, or you can go way further than with conventionnal engines for the same amount of fuel. Note that this is only true in vacuum, as its specific impulse in atmosphere is similar to the other engines.

However, since it has a very low thrust, the burns will need quite some time to be completed, which isn't a problem when dealing with interplanetary distances.

Low thrust and long burn times can royally mess up well timed interplanetary travel.

For the moment, im sticking with the 'real' LFE's.
I am loving it. with sutch high impulse in vaccum, it is perfect for interplanetary transfers!
Good luck getting to Jool without one.

This engine have thrust only 60, what it's advantage over other engines?

Once in orbit, thrust only determines how long you have to burn in order to make orbital maneuvers. However, the engine has an Isp (Specific Impulse) of 800 which makes it twice as efficient as the small LV909 engine.

Only issue I've had with these engines is that, when using them for interplanetary transfers, one tends to have to get a parking orbit in high kerbin orbit in order for the window of opportunity to be long enough that the transfer is successful... by the time I reach escape velocity I'm extremely far from the escape angle, and it makes the transfers nigh impossible. Should I start thrusting before I reach the ejection angle?
It is one of the most efficient engines in the game, making it non-op due to it's low thrust... I LIKE IT
I like it. I feel like it is the only thing that keeps me from cheating for infinite fuel

For low acceleration for a long trip. So that you actually have the fuel to get back again...

Once our of the atmosphere and in orbit low thrust is irrelevant (assuming you don't mind how long the trip takes).
i wish there is a nuclear fuel tank

i wish there is a nuclear fuel tank

Why? The best liquid rocket fuel and the best nuclear thermal rocket propellant are the same thing... hydrogen.

Yes, the liquid rocket fuel tanks also include the oxidizer, but NTRs can use that as propellant too... just not as efficiently as the hydrogen due to its greater mass. However, considering that real NTRs would be able achieve in excess of 900 seconds Isp, they may already be taking this efficiency loss into account with the fuel tanks.

im sticking with the 'real' LFE's.

Nuclear thermal rockets are real. Design of the first one began in the late 1950s. They've even been ground tested. They just haven't flown in space.
